title: U.S. President George Washington gives the first State of the Union Address.
Mozart's opera quotCosi Fan Tuttequot premiered in Vienna.
The first boat specialized as a lifeboat is tested on the River Tyne.
In New York City the Supreme Court of the United States convenes for the first time.
Louis XVI of France declares to the National Assembly that he will maintain the constitutional laws.
Two Quaker delegates petition the United States Congress for the abolition of slavery.
The first United States census is authorized.
France is divided into 83 départements, which cut across the former provinces, in an attempt to dislodge regional loyalties based on noble ownership of land.
Thomas Jefferson reports to President George Washington in New York as the new United States Secretary of State.
The United States patent system is established.

Battle of Reval: Gustav III of Sweden sends the battlefleet to eliminate the Russian squadron wintering at Reval (Estonia), but is defeated: 8 Russians, 51 Swedes are killed, 250 captured, and 2 ships are sunk.
Rhode Island ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the last of the 13 original states to do so.
Royal Assent Given To The Town Of Milford Haven.

Compromise of 1790: Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and Alexander Hamilton come to an agreement: Madison agrees to not be quotstrenuousquot in opposition for the assumption of state debts by the federal government Hamilton agrees to support the capital site being above the Potomac.
The alleged ''London Monster'' is arrested in London: he later receives 40 years for 10 assaults.
July ampampndash Louis XVI of France accepts a constitutional monarchy.

Russo-Swedish War ampndash Second Battle of Svensksund: In a massive Baltic Sea battle of 300 ships, the Swedish navy captures one third of the Russian fleet: 304 Swedes are killed, 3,500 Russians killed and 6,000 captured, 51 Russian ships are sunk and 22 are taken.

French Revolution: The Civil Constitution of the Clergy is passed. This completes the destruction of the monastic orders, legislating out of existence all regular and secular chapters for either sex, abbacies and priorships.
French Revolution: Citizens of Paris celebrate the constitutional monarchy and national reconciliation in the Fête de la Fédération.
The signing of the Residence Bill establishes a site along the Potomac River as the District of Columbia, the capital district of the United States
The Convention of Reichenbach is signed between Prussia and Austria.
Inventor Samuel Hopkins becomes the first to be issued a U.S. patent (for an improved method of making potash).
A newly passed U.S. tariff act creates the system of cutters for revenue enforcement (later named the United States Revenue Cutter Service), the forerunner of the Coast Guard.
The Treaty of Värälä ends the Russo-Swedish War.
Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor starts to rule.
The Hawkesbury and Nepean Wars begins in New South Wales, Australia as a result of deterioration in relations and increasing colonization.
Russo-Turkish War, 1787-1792: 26,000 Turkish soldiers lose their lives during Suvorov's storm of Izmail.
The British Parliament passes the Constitutional Act of 1791, splitting the old province of Quebec into Upper and Lower Canada.
Long-distance communication speeds up with the unveiling of a semaphore machine in Paris.
Vermont is admitted as the 14th U.S. state.
The first of forty boundary stones delineating the borders of the new District of Columbia is laid at Jones Point Light, in Alexandria, Virginia.
The Sejm  of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth proclaims the Constitution of May 3, 1791, the first modern codified constitution in Europe.
The French Royal Family is captured when they try to flee in disguise.
Composer Joseph Haydn awarded an honorary doctorate of music at Oxford University.
The Priestley Riots break out in Birmingham, England.
The Champ de Mars Massacre occurs during the French Revolution.
The Treaty of Sistova is signed, ending the Ottoman-Habsburg wars.
The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin is finished.
A slave rebellion breaks out in the French colony of Saint-Domingue.
John Fitch is granted a patent for the steamboat in the United States.
Louis XVI of France accepts the final version of the completed constitution.
Mission Santa Cruz is founded by Father Fermín Francisco de Lasuén, becoming the 12th mission in the California mission chain.
promulgation of the law  on the emancipation of the french jews.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's singspiel ''Die Zauberflöte'' ''(Magic Flute)'' premieres in the Freihaustheater in Vienna.
October ampampndash The Legislative Assembly (France) convenes.
Mission Nuestra Señora de la Soledad is founded by Father Fermín Francisco de Lasuén, becoming the 13th mission in the California mission chain.
The first issue of ''The Observer'', the world's first Sunday newspaper, is published.
Austrian composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart dies.

Ratification by the states of the first ten amendments to the United States Constitution is completed, creating the United States Bill of Rights. Two additional amendments remain pending, and one of these is finally ratified in 1992, becoming the Twenty-seventh Amendment.
The Treaty of Jassy ends Russia's war with the Ottoman Empire over Crimea.
The Postal Service Act, establishing the United States Post Office Department, is signed by President George Washington.
Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor, the last emperor, takes office.
King Gustav III of Sweden is shot in the back by Jacob Johan Anckarström at a midnight masquerade at the Royal Opera in Stockholm he lives until March 29, and is succeeded by Gustav IV Adolf.

A new capital of North Carolina and county seat of the newly formed Wake County is established after North Carolina State Senator and surveyor William Christmas submits his design for the city.  A few months later the capital is officially named Raleigh in honor of Sir Walter Raleigh.
The Coinage Act is passed, establishing the United States Mint.
United States President George Washington vetoes a bill designed to apportion representatives among U.S. states. This is the first time the presidential veto is used in the United States.
France declares war against Austria.
Tiradentes, prime figure in the Inconfidência Mineira plot, is executed in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
The guillotine is first used experimentally in France.
Highwayman Nicolas J. Pelletier becomes the first person executed by guillotine.
''La Marseillaise'', the French national anthem, is composed by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle.
The Revenue Commission is established.
Captain Robert Gray on the ''Columbia Rediviva'' becomes the first white man to enter the Columbia River.
The Buttonwood Agreement is signed, beginning the New York Stock Exchange.
War in defence of the constitution: Russia invades Poland.
An old lava dome collapses in Kyūshū, Japan when Mount Unzen volcano erupts the resulting avalanche and tsunami kills about 14,300 people.
Kentucky becomes the 15th state of The United States of America.
Captain George Vancouver claims Puget Sound for Great Britain.
Vancouver becomes the first European to enter Burrard Inlet.
Prussia declares war against France.
French Revolution: The Tuileries Palace is stormed, and Louis XVI of France is arrested and taken into custody.
September ampampndash George Macartney, 1st Earl Macartney sails from Portsmouth to China.
During what becomes known as the September Massacres of the French Revolution, rampaging mobs slaughter 3 Roman Catholic Church bishops and more than 200 priests.
Six men steal some of the former French Crown jewels from a warehouse where the revolutionary government had stored them.
Battle of Valmy: The French revolutionary army defeats Prussians under the Duke of Brunswick, after a 7-hour artillery duel.
The French Convention abolishes the monarchy and establishes the First Republic.
The Era of the historical French Republican Calendar begins.
The first Columbus Day celebration in the USA is held in New York, 300 years after his arrival in the New World.
Foundation of Washington, DC: The cornerstone of the United States Executive Mansion, known as the White House after 1818, is laid.
Mount Hood (Oregon) is named after the British naval officer Samuel Hood by Lt. William E. Broughton, who spots the mountain near the mouth of the Willamette River.
George Washington is re-elected President of the United States.
The trial of Louis XVI of France begins.
Russia and Prussia partition the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.
Jean-Pierre Blanchard becomes the first to fly in a gas balloon in the United States.
After being found guilty of treason by the French Convention, ''Citizen Capet'', Louis XVI of France, is guillotined.
French Revolutionary Wars: France declares war on Great Britain and the Netherlands.
George Washington holds the first Cabinet meeting as President of the United States.
The Giles resolutions are introduced to the United States House of Representatives, asking the House to condemn Alexander Hamilton's handling of loans.
3 ampndash John Langdon serves as President pro tempore of the United States Senate.
George Washington is sworn in as President of the United States in Philadelphia for his second term.
French troops are defeated by Austrian forces and Liège is recaptured.
France declares war on Spain.
The first republican state in Germany, the Republic of Mainz, is declared by Andreas Joseph Hofmann.
The Committee of Public Safety is established in France with Georges Danton as its head.
George Washington signs the Neutrality Proclamation.
The pioneer parishes of New Orleans and Louisiana are erected as well as incorporated into the Diocese of Louisiana and the Two Floridas
Regular troops under François Hanriot demand that the Girondins be expelled from the national convention.
The Girondins are overthrown in France.

The Jardin des Plantes and the Muséum national d'histoire naturelle are created by the National Convention. The museum opens in Paris the following year and the garden houses one of the first public zoos.
The Act Against Slavery is passed in Upper Canada.
Charlotte Corday kills Jean-Paul Marat in his bath.
Charlotte Corday is executed.

Scottish explorer Alexander Mackenzie's 1792ampndash1793 Peace River expedition to the Pacific Ocean reaches its goal at Bella Coola, British Columbia, making him the first known person to complete a transcontinental crossing of northern North America.
John Graves Simcoe decides to build a fort and settlement at Toronto, having sailed into the bay there.
French Revolution ampndash Feast of Unity: Crowds in Paris burn monarchist emblems.

The following universal conscription decree is enacted in France: quotThe young men shall go to battle and the married men shall forge arms. The women shall make tents and clothes and shall serve in the hospitals children shall tear rags into lint. The old men will be guided to the public places of the cities to kindle the courage of the young warriors and to preach the unity of the Republic and the hatred of kings.quot
In Paris, the Louvre Palace is opened to the public as a museum.
The French Republican Calendar is adopted by the National Convention.
The dechristianisation of France during the French Revolution reaches a climax with the celebration of the Goddess quotReasonquot in the cathedral of Notre Dame de Paris.
Madame du Barry is executed.
New York City's first daily newspaper, the ''American Minerva'', is established by Noah Webster.

French forces under Dugommier capture Toulon from royalists and British forces under Vice Admiral Lord Hood. The British fire the dockyards and take 16 ships, one of which, the ''Lutine'', becomes a famous treasure ship.
The First Coalition against France is formed during the year by Great Britain, the Dutch Republic, Spain, Portugal, the Holy Roman Empire, Naples and Tuscany.
The Al Bu Falah move to Abu Dhabi.
The first year of regular production begins for the United States Mint and the half cent is minted for the first time.
In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania more than 4,000 die from yellow fever.
Niccolò Paganini debuts as a violin virtuoso at age 11.
The French Republic abolishes slavery.
The first session of the United States Senate is open to the public.
Canonsburg Academy (now Washington amp Jefferson College) is chartered by the General Assembly.
Eli Whitney is granted a patent for the cotton gin.
Georges Danton is executed.
May 1 ampndash Battle of Boulou: The French defeat the Spanish  and Portuguese forces.
French chemist Antoine Lavoisier is executed by guillotine.
Battle of Tourcoing: French troops defeat British forces.
June 1 ampndash The Glorious First of June (Battle of Ushant): British and French ships battle to a draw.
British troops capture Port-au-Prince in Haiti.

Battle of Fleurus: French forces defeat the Austrians and their allies, leading to permanent loss of the Austrian Netherlands and destruction of the Dutch Republic. French use of an observation balloon marks the first participation of an aircraft in battle.
Horatio Nelson loses the sight in his right eye at Calvi in Corsica.
(9 Thermidor) ampndash Maximilien Robespierre is arrested.  Executed the next day.
The University of Tennessee is established at Knoxville.
October ampampndash A Federal army quells the Whiskey Rebellion in the United States.
Russian General Alexander Suvorov stormed Warsaw in the war against the Polish uprising and captured Praga, one of its suburbs, killing many civilians.
The first recorded meeting of the Franklin Literary Society was held at Canonsburg Academy (now Washington amp Jefferson College).
The University of North Carolina opens to students at Chapel Hill, becoming the first state university in the United States.
The French occupy Utrecht, Netherlands.
Revolution breaks out in Amsterdam.
The Batavian Republic is proclaimed.
French troops enter Amsterdam.
The Dutch fleet, frozen in IJsselmeer, is captured by the French 8th Hussars.
The Eleventh Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed.
March ampampndash English Benedictine monks expelled from Douai are permitted to proceed to England.
Peace of Basel signed between France and Prussia.
Adoption of the metric system in France.
George, Prince of Wales, marries Caroline of Brunswick.
Battle of Nu'uanu: Kamehameha I of the Island of Hawaii defeats the Oahuans, solidifying his control of the major islands of the archipelago and officially founding the Kingdom of Hawaii.
War of the First Coalition: Napoleon I of France enters Milan in triumph.
MayampampndashJune ampampndash The ''Battle of Richmond Hill'' is fought in the colony of New South Wales, between the Darug people and British colonial forces.
7 ampndash The Copenhagen fire of 1795, starting in a naval warehouse, destroys 941 houses.
The Dauphin, would-be-Louis XVII, dies. Louis XVIII becomes titular king of France (he becomes the actual king on April 6, 1814).
The French government announces that the heir to the French throne has died of illness (many doubt the statement).
Mary Robinson writes the poem ''January, 1795''.
British forces land off Quiberon to aid the revolt in Brittany.
French troops recapture St. Lucia.
Second Treaty of Basel between the French First Republic and Spain, ending the War of the Pyrenees. Spain cedes its half of the Caribbean island of Hispaniola to France.
Construction of the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct in Wales begins.
Signing of the Treaty of Greenville puts an end to the Northwest Indian War.
The French Constitution of 1795 is ratified by the National Convention.
Third Treaty of Basel between the French First Republic and the Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel.
Battle of Krtsanisi.
Battle of the Diamond: Protestant forces defeat Catholic troops in Loughgall, Ireland, leading to the foundation of the Orange Order.
Austrian Netherlands is annexed to the French Republic as the ''Belgian departments''.
13 Vendémiaire: Royalist riots in Paris are crushed by troops under Paul Barras and newly reinstalled artillery officer Napoleon Bonaparte.
The Third Partition of Poland is made.
The United States and Spain sign the Treaty of Madrid, which establishes the boundaries between Spanish colonies and the U.S.
The French Directory takes power. Influence of the Sans-culottes declines.

Wold Newton meteorite: A meteorite falls at Wold Newton, a hamlet in Yorkshire in England. This meteorite fall is subsequently used as a literary premise by science fiction writer Philip José Farmer as the basis for the Wold Newton family.
Sweden becomes the first monarchy to recognize the French Republic.
The Hudson's Bay Company trading post Fort Edmonton is constructed the city of Edmonton, Alberta, eventually grows from it.
A large slave rebellion occurs in Curaçao.

The British Royal Navy makes the use of lemon juice mandatory to prevent scurvy.ampamp{{cite book|first=Stephen R.|last=Bown|title=Scurvy: How a Surgeon, a Mariner and a Gentleman Solved the Greatest Medical Mystery of the Age of Sail|publisher=Penguin Books Australia|year=2003|page=222}}ampamp
The harvest fails in Munich.
Daniel McGinnis discovers the supposed Money Pit on Oak Island, Nova Scotia.
The first Dutch (and general) elections are held for the National Assembly of the Batavian Republic (the next Dutch general elections are held in 1888).
The capital of Upper Canada is moved from Newark to York.
The Qianlong Emperor abdicates at age 84 to make way for his son, the Jiaqing Emperor.
The Kingdom of Great Britain is granted control of Ceylon by the Dutch.
Widow Joséphine de Beauharnais marries General Napoléon Bonaparte.
Carl Gauss obtains conditions for the constructibility by ruler and compass of regular polygons, and is able to announce that the regular 17-gon is constructible by ruler and compasses.
The only night of the would-be Shakespearean play ''Vortigern and Rowena'' (actually written by William Henry Ireland) ends in the audience's laughter.
War of the First Coalition ampndash Battle of Montenotte: Napoleon Bonaparte gains his first victory as an army commander.
Case of the Lyons Mail: During the night of April 27, 5 highwaymen attack the mail between Paris and Lyon, kill the postmen, and steal the funds sent to the armies in Italy.
Persian Expedition of 1796: Russian troops storm Derbent.

War of the First Coalition ampampndash Battle of Lodi: General Napoleon Bonaparte defeats Austrian rearguard in forcing a crossing of the bridge over the River Adda in Italy. The Austrians lose some 2,000 men, 14 guns, and 30 ammunition wagons.
Edward Jenner administers the first smallpox vaccination.
Napoleon's troops take Milan.
The last mock Garrat Elections are held in Surrey, England.
Tennessee is admitted as the 16th U.S. state.
Carl Friedrich Gauss discovers that every positive integer is representable as a sum of at most 3 triangular numbers.
The United States takes possession of Detroit from Great Britain under the terms of the Jay Treaty.
Mungo Park reaches Ségou, the capital of the Bamana Empire.
Surveyors of the Connecticut Land Company name an area in Ohio quotClevelandquot after Gen. Moses Cleaveland, the superintendent of the surveying party.

Opening to traffic of the Wearmouth Bridge in England, designed by Thomas Paine in cast iron. Its span of 72 m (237 feet) makes it the world's longest single-span vehicular bridge extant at this date.
French Revolutionary Wars ampndash Battle of Bassano: French forces defeat Austrian troops.
U.S. President George Washington issues his ''Farewell Address'', which warns against partisan politics and foreign entanglements.
John Adams defeats Thomas Jefferson in the U.S. presidential election.
The Treaty of Tripoli (between the United States and Tripoli) is signed at Tripoli (see also 1797).
O.S.) ampndash Catherine II of Russia (called ''Catherine The Great'') dies and is succeeded by her son Paul I of Russia. His wife Sophie Marie Dorothea of Württemberg becomes Empress consort.
French Revolutionary Wars ampndash Battle of Arcole: French forces defeat the Austrians in Italy.
The U.S. Electoral College meets to elect John Adams president.
The Treaty of Tripoli (a peace treaty between the United States and Tripoli) is signed at Algiers (see also 1796).
The parliament of the Cisalpine Republic adopts the Italian green-white-red tricolour as the official flag (this is considered the birth of the flag of Italy).
London haberdasher John Hetherington wears a silk top hat in public and attracts a large crowd of onlookers. He is later fined £500 for causing a public nuisance.
The Battle of Cape St. Vincent (1797), part of the Wars of the French Revolution.
Spanish Governor José Maria Chacón peacefully surrenders the colony of Trinidad to a British naval force commanded by Sir Ralph Abercromby.
The Last invasion of Britain begins. French forces under the command of American Colonel William Tate land near Fishguard in Wales.
William Tate surrenders to the British at Fishguard.
The Bank of England (national bank of Britain) issues the first one-pound and two-pound notes (discontinued March 11, 1988).
John Adams is sworn in as the second President of the United States of America.
Spithead and Nore mutinies.

Sir Ralph Abercromby unsuccessfully invades San Juan, Puerto Rico in what will be one of the largest British attacks on Spanish territories in the western hemisphere, and one of the worst defeats of the English navy for years to come.
The first ship of the United States Navy, the frigate ''USS UNITED STATES'', is commissioned.
First Coalition: Napoleon I of France conquers Venice, ending the city's 1,100 years of independence. The last doge of Venice, Ludovico Manin, steps down.
William Wilberforce marries Barbara Ann Spooner.
Horatio Nelson is wounded at the Battle of Santa Cruz, losing an arm.
The Treaty of Campo Formio ends the War of the First Coalition.
In Boston Harbor, the 44-gun United States Navy frigate ''USS Constitution'' is launched to fight Barbary pirates off the coast of Tripoli.
Napoleon leads a successful French charge against Fort l'Aiguilette to secure Toulon.
A coup d'état is staged in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic). Unitarian Democrat Pieter Vreede makes an end to the power of the parliament (with a conservative-moderate majority).
The papacy is removed from power by French General Louis Alexandre Berthier.
French troops enter Bern.
French forces invade the Papal States and establish the Roman Republic.

The Mississippi Territory is organized by the United States from territory ceded by Georgia and South Carolina later it is twice expanded to include disputed territory claimed by both the U.S. and Spain (which acquired territory in trade with Great Britain).
Helvetic Republic, a French client republic, proclaimed following collapse of the Old Swiss Confederacy on French invasion.
France annexes Geneva.

Irish republicans and nationalists, known as the Society of United Irishmen, launch a rebellion against British rule in expectation of support from France. The United Irishmen are unique amongst Irish nationalist movements in that they unify Catholics and Protestants around republican ideals. The rebellion rages sporadically but is defeated by the British by October.
The French take Malta.
A moderate ''coup d'état'' in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic) deposes Pieter Vreede.
Mission San Luis Rey de Francia is founded.
Napoleon's troops land in Egypt.
Quasi-War: The United States Congress rescinds treaties with France, sparking the war.
The United States Marine Corps is re/established.
Battle of Shubra Khit between French and Mamelukes, during Napoleon's march from Alexandria to take Cairo.
The Alien and Sedition Acts become United States law, making it a federal crime to write, publish, or utter false or malicious statements about the United States government.
The Relief of Sick and Disabled Seamen Act is signed into law, creating the Marine Hospital Service, the forerunner to the current United States Public Health Service Commissioned Corps.
Battle of the Pyramids: Napoleon defeats Ottoman forces near the Pyramids.
Napoleon occupies Cairo.
A second round of elections are held in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic) no general elections this time.
Battle of the Nile (near Abu Qir): Lord Nelson defeats the French navy under Admiral Brueys Nelson himself is wounded in the head.
French troops land at Kilcummin in County Mayo to assist the Irish rebellion.
September ampampndash Charles Brockden Brown publishes the first significant American novel, the Gothic fiction ''Wieland: or, The Transformation an American Tale''.
Battle of St. George's Caye: Off the coast of British Honduras (now Belize), a group of British nationals and African slaves defeat a force sent from Mexico to drive them out.
''Lyrical Ballads'' is published anonymously by Samuel Taylor Coleridge and William Wordsworth, inaugurating the English Romantic movement in literature.

Battle of Tory Island: A British Royal Navy squadron under Sir John Borlase Warren prevents French Republican ships commanded by Jean-Baptiste-François Bompart landing reinforcements for the Society of United Irishmen on the Donegal coast Irish leader Wolfe Tone is captured and later dies of wounds.
Beginning of the Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu.
British whaler John Fearn becomes the first European to land on Nauru.
British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the Napoleonic Wars.
Federalist James Ross becomes President Pro Tempore of the United States Senate.
The Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu ends with the surrender of the French garrison.
Napoleon captures Jaffa in Palestine and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.
New York passes a law aimed at gradually abolishing slavery in the state.
Battle of Seringapatam: Tippu Sultan is defeated and killed by the British.
Siege of Acre ends after two months: Napoleon's attempt to widen his Middle Eastern campaign into Syria is frustrated by Ottoman forces, and he withdraws to Egypt.
Battle of Winterthur: Habsburg forces secure control of north east Switzerland from the French Army of the Danube.
Ranjit Singh's men take their positions outside Lahore.
Ranjit Singh the Great conquers Lahore and becomes ruler of the Punjab.
In the Egyptian port city of Rosetta, French Captain Pierre Bouchard finds the Rosetta Stone.
At Aboukir in Egypt, Napoleon defeats 10,000 Ottoman Mamluk troops under Mustafa Pasha.
War of the Second Coalition: Anglo-Russian invasion of Holland ampndash Britain and Russia send an expedition to the Batavian Republic.

Anglo-Russian invasion of Holland: Vlieter Incident: A squadron of the Batavian Republic's navy, commanded by Rear-Admiral Samuel Story, surrenders to the British Royal Navy under Sir Ralph Abercromby and Admiral Sir Charles Mitchell near Wieringen without joining action.
Anglo-Russian invasion of Holland: Battle of Castricum ampndash Franco-Dutch forces defeat the Russo-British expedition force.
{{HMS|Lutine|1779}} (a famous treasure wreck) is sunk in the West Frisian Islands.
Jeanne Geneviève Labrosse becomess the first woman to jump from a balloon with a parachute, from an altitude of 900 meters.
Anglo-Russian invasion of Holland: Anglo-Russian expedition forces surrender in North Holland.
Napoleon overthrows the French Directory.
December
A new constitution is approved in a plebiscite in France.
Napoleon becomes First Consul.
George Washington, the first President of the United States, dies in Mount Vernon, Virginia.
Dutch East India Company dissolves
The Bank of France is founded.
United Irishman Roddy McCorley is executed in Toomebridge for his part in the Irish Rebellion of 1798.
Cardinal Barnaba Chiaramonti succeeds Pius VI as Pius VII, the 251st pope.
Alessandro Volta describes his new invention, the voltaic pile, the first chemical battery, in a letter to the Royal Society.
April ampampndash Voting begins in the United States presidential election, 1800 it will last until October. The result is not announced until February 1801.
The U.S. Library of Congress is founded.
Great Britain passes the Act of Union to join Great Britain and Ireland into the United Kingdom (to take effect on 1 January 1801). The act is signed by King George III in August.
Napoleon Bonaparte crosses the Alps and invades Italy.
First smallpox vaccination is made in North America, at Trinity, Newfoundland.
Battle of Marengo: Napoleon defeats the Austrian troops near Marengo, Italy.
At the invitation of the Maltese, British troops liberate the Islands of Malta and Gozo from the French.
The Convention of 1800, or Treaty of Mortefontaine, is signed between France and the United States of America, ending the Quasi-War.
U.S. President John Adams becomes the first President of the United States to live in the Executive Mansion (later renamed the White House).
Middlebury College is granted its charter by the Vermont General Assembly.
The U.S. Congress holds its first Washington, D.C. session.
Battle of Hohenlinden: the French army defeats German troops.
An assault on Napoleon Bonaparte fails in Paris.
Pierre Coudrin and Henriette Aymer de la Chevalerie found the Congregation of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Paris.
Christmas Day first becomes a Public Holiday on an international scale.
Toussaint L'Ouverture triumphantly enters Santo Domingo, the capital of the former Spanish colony of Santo Domingo, which has become a colony of Napoleonic France.
John Marshall is appointed Chief Justice of the United States.
William Pitt the Younger resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The Treaty of Lunéville ends the War of the Second Coalition between France and Austria.
An electoral tie between Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr is resolved, when Jefferson is elected President of the United States and Burr Vice President by the United States House of Representatives.
Washington, D.C. is placed under the jurisdiction of the Congress of the United States.
Thomas Jefferson succeeds John Adams as President of the United States of America.
Henry Addington becomes First Lord of the Treasury and Chancellor of the Exchequer effectively Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Second Battle of Abukir in Egypt: British troops defeat the French, but the British commander, Sir Ralph Abercromby, dies later of a wound received in the action.
Tsar Paul I of Russia is murdered. He is succeeded by his son Alexander I.
First Battle of Copenhagen: The British fleet under Admiral Sir Hyde Parker, along with Admiral Horatio Nelson, attack Copenhagen the Armed Neutrality of the North is dissolved.
The pascha of Tripoli declares war on the United States by having the flagpole on the consulate chopped down.
Portugal and Spain sign the Treaty of Badajoz Portugal loses the city of Olivenza.
Cairo falls to British troops.
Battle of Algeciras: The French fleet defeats the British fleet.
Napoleon signs a Concordat with Pope Pius VII.
The Treaty of London is signed for preliminary peace between the First French Republic and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
A coup d'état is staged in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic).
The first edition of ''New-York Evening Post'' is printed.
Canonsburg Academy (now Washington amp Jefferson College) is chartered by the Pennsylvania General Assembly.
Army Corps of Engineers re-established.
The United States Military Academy at West Point is established.
March 27 ampndash Napoleonic Wars: The Treaty of Amiens between France and the United Kingdom ends the War of the Second Coalition.
H. W. Olbers discovers the asteroid Pallas.
Revenue Commission disbanded.
Great Trigonometric Survey of India begins with the measurement of a baseline near Madras.

A general amnesty signed by Napoleon Bonaparte allows all but about 1,000 of the most notorious émigrés of the French Revolution to return to France, as part of a reconciliary gesture to make peace with the various factions of the ''Ancien Regime'' that ultimately consolidates his own rule.
Napoleon Bonaparte establishes the French ''Légion d'honneur'' (Legion of Honour).
By the Law of 20 May 1802, Napoleon Bonaparte reinstates slavery in the French colonies, revoking its abolition in the French Revolution.
Patent and Trademark Office within Department of State
Indigenous Australian Pemulwuy, a leader of the resistance to European settlement of Australia, is shot dead by Henry Hacking.
Haitian revolutionary Toussaint L'Ouverture is seized by French troops and is imprisoned at the Fort de Joux.
June ampampndash Gia Long is crowned as first Emperor of the Nguyễn Dynasty in Vietnam.
July ampampndash Eleuthère Irénée du Pont founds E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, the modern DuPont Company.
At West Point, New York the United States Military Academy opens.
August 28 ampndash A general election in the United Kingdom brings victory for the Tories, led by Henry Addington.
Gia Long captures Hanoi, completing his unification of Vietnam.
In a plebiscite, Napoleon Bonaparte is confirmed as the First Consul.
William Wordsworth publishes the poem ''Westminster Bridge''.
The Italian region of Piedmont becomes a part of the French First Republic.
War ends between Sweden and Tripoli. The United States also negotiates peace, but war continues over the size of compensation.
October ampampndash The French army enters Switzerland.
William Symington demonstrates his ''Charlotte Dundas'', the quotfirst practical steamboatquot, in Scotland.
Monroe and Livingston sail for Paris to discuss, and possibly buy, New Orleans they end up completing the Louisiana Purchase.

Act of Mediation issued by Napoleon Bonaparte establishes the Swiss Confederation to replace the Helvetic Republic. Under the terms of the act, Graubünden, St. Gallen, Thurgau, the Ticino and Vaud become Swiss cantons.
Edward Despard and six others are hanged and beheaded for plotting to assassinate King George III of the United Kingdom and to destroy the Bank of England.
''Marbury v. Madison'': The Supreme Court of the United States establishes the principle of judicial review.
A major redistribution of territorial sovereignty within the Holy Roman Empire is enacted via an act known as the Reichsdeputationshauptschluss.
Ohio is admitted as the 17th U.S. state, retroactive from August 7, 1953.
Aargau becomes a Swiss canton.
MarchampampndashApril ampampndash The ''franc germinal'' is introduced in France.
Louisiana Purchase is made by the United States from France.
May ampampndash The First Consul of France Citizen Bonaparte begins making preparations to invade England.
Master Malati, a Coptic Christian leader, is beheaded by a Muslim mob in Cairo, Egypt.
The Louisiana Purchase is announced to the American people.
The convention of Artlenburg leads to the French occupation of Hanover (which had been ruled by the British king).
Robert Emmet's uprising in Ireland begins.
The wagonway between Wandsworth and Croydon is opened, being the first public railway line in England.
The British begin the Second Anglo-Maratha War against Sindhia of Gwalior.
William Wordsworth writes quotUpon Westminster Bridge.quot
Battle of Delhi, during the Second Anglo-Maratha War, between British troops under General Lake, and Marathas of Scindia's army under General Louis Bourquin.
Irish rebel Robert Emmet is executed.
Battle of Assaye (India): British-led troops defeat Maratha forces.
The Senate ratifies the Louisiana Purchase Treaty, doubling the size of the United States.
Battle of Vertières: The Haitian army led by Jean-Jacques Dessalines defeats the army of Napoleon.
Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin begins removal of the Elgin Marbles from the Parthenon in Athens where they are at risk of destruction during the Ottoman occupation of Greece.
Orissa, India is occupied by the British under the British East India Company after the Second Anglo-Maratha War.
Major breakthroughs in chemistry occur, with the identification of the elements Rhodium, Palladium, Osmium, Iridium, and Cerium.
Haiti gains independence from France and becomes the first black republic, having the only successful slave revolt ever.
The First Serbian Uprising begins as an intro into Serbian Revolution. By 1817, Principality of Serbia proclaims self-rule from Ottoman Empire, thus becoming the first nation-state in Europe.
New Jersey becomes the last northern state to abolish slavery.
First Barbary War: Stephen Decatur leads a raid to burn the pirate-held frigate ''Philadelphia''.
The USS ''Philadelphia'' burns.
Ohio University is chartered by the Ohio General Assembly.

The Cornishman Richard Trevithick's newly-built quotPenydarrenquot steam locomotive operates on the Merthyr Tramroad between Penydarren in Merthyr Tydfil and Abercynon in South Wales, following several trials since February 13, the world's first locomotive to work on rails.
February ampampndash The 1804 Haiti Massacre, an ethnic cleansing, eradicates the white population on Haiti it is not stopped until 22 April.
Louisiana Purchase: In St. Louis, a formal ceremony is conducted to transfer ownership of Louisiana Territory from France to the United States.
First performance of Friedrich Schiller's play ''Wilhelm Tell'', at Weimar under the direction of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.
The ''Napoleonic Code'' is adopted as French civil law.
Forty merchantmen are wrecked when a convoy led by the HMS ''Apollo'' runs aground off Portugal.
Samuel Taylor Coleridge aboard ''The Speedwell'' sails to the Mediterranean
The first recorded meteorite falls in Possil, Scotland (High Possil meteorite).
Henry Addington resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
William Pitt the Younger begins his second term as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The Lewis and Clark Expedition departs from Camp Dubois and begins their historic journey by traveling up the Missouri River.
Napoleon Bonaparte is proclaimed Emperor of the French by the French Senate.
Beethoven's ''Symphony No. 3 in Eampndashflat'' premiered in Vienna.
The Twelfth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified by New Hampshire, and arguably becomes effective (subsequently vetoed by the Governor of New Hampshire).
Alexander Hamilton is shot during a duel with Aaron Burr and dies the next day.
The Twelfth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution ratified by Tennessee, removing doubt surrounding adoption.

Lewis and Clark Expedition: The ''Corps of Discovery'', whose purpose is to explore the Louisiana Purchase, suffers its only death when Sergeant Charles Floyd dies, apparently from acute appendicitis.
German astronomer K. L. Harding discovers the asteroid Juno.

The Treaty of St. Louis (1804) is signed by Quashquame and William Henry Harrison controversy surrounding the treaty eventually causes the Sauks to ally with the British during the War of 1812 and is the main cause of the Black Hawk War of 1832.
Said bin Sultan, Sultan of Muscat and Oman starts to rule.

The Democratic-Republican-controlled United States Senate begin an impeachment trial against Federalist-partisan Supreme Court of the United States Justice Samuel Chase (he was charged with political bias but was acquitted by the United States Senate of all charges on March 1, 1805).
At Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself as the first Emperor of the French in a thousand years (the Napoleonic Code is adopted).
Thomas Jefferson defeats Charles C. Pinckney in the U.S. presidential election.
Spain declares war on Britain
Michigan Territory is created.
The Harmony Society is officially formed.
Justice Samuel Chase is acquitted of impeachment charges by the U.S. Senate.
Thomas Jefferson is sworn in for a second term as President of the United States.
The New Brunswick Legislature passes a bill to advance literacy in the province, which eventually leads to the creation of public education in what is now Canada.
United States Marines and Berbers attack the Tripolitan city of Derna (The quotShores of Tripoliquot).
Rutger Jan Schimmelpenninck is appointed as Grand Pensionary of the Batavian Republic by Napoleon.
Luigi Boccherini is buried in Italy after being found dead on May 28.
The First Barbary War ends between Tripoli and the United States of America.
The first Trooping the Colour ceremony is held at the Horse Guards Parade in London.
Detroit burns to the ground most of the city is destroyed.
Lewis and Clark Expedition: Scouting ahead of the expedition, Meriwether Lewis and four companions sight the Great Falls of the Missouri River, confirming they are heading in the right direction.
Muhammad Ali Pasha founds his dynasty in Egypt.
Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Ulm: Austrian General Mack von Leiberich is forced to surrender his entire army to Napoleon after being surrounded.

Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Trafalgar: British naval  fleet led by Admiral Horatio Nelson defeats a combined French and Spanish fleet off the coast of Spain however, Admiral Nelson is fatally shot.
The Lewis and Clark Expedition arrives at the Pacific Ocean.
Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Dürenstein: 8,000 French troops attempt to slow the retreat of a vastly superior Russian and Austrian force.
Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Schöngrabern: ampndash Russian forces under Pyotr Bagration delay the pursuit by French troops under Murat.
The Pontcysyllte Aqueduct is opened.
Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Austerlitz: French troops  under Napoleon decisively defeat a joint Russo-Austrian force.
The Peace of Pressburg is signed between France and Austria.
Kingdom of Bavaria established by Napoleon.
The body of Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson, lies in state in the Painted Hall of the Greenwich Hospital prior to his funeral.
Cape Colony becomes a British colony.
Lord Nelson is given a state funeral at St Paul's Cathedral, attended by the Prince of Wales.Hibbert, Christopher ''Nelson: A Personal History'' (1994) p. 382
The Dutch in Cape Town surrender to the British.
The British occupy the Cape of Good Hope.
Grenville succeeds William Pitt the Younger as wartime Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, upon Pitt's death this day amidst worsening health caused by the stresses of the Napoleonic Wars.
The Royal Navy gains a victory off Santo Domingo (see Action of 6 February 1806).
After traveling through the Louisiana Purchase and reaching the Pacific Ocean, explorers Lewis and Clark and their ''Corps of Discovery'' begin their journey home.
Washington College (now Washington amp Jefferson College) is chartered by the Pennsylvania General Assembly.
Construction is authorized of the ''National Road'' (the first United States federal highway).
Stephanie de Beauharnais, adopted daughter of Napoleon Bonaparte, marries Prince Karl Ludwig Friedrich of Baden.
Andrew Jackson kills a man in a duel after the man had accused Jackson's wife of bigamy.
Louis Bonaparte is appointed as King of Holland by his brother, Emperor Napoleon I.
Battle of Maida: Britain defeats the French in Calabria. The legendary ''Irish Rover'' sets sail from the Cove of Cork, Ireland for New York City.
Vellore Mutiny, the first mutiny by Indian sepoys against the British East India Company.
Pike expedition: Near St. Louis, Missouri, United States Army Lieutenant Zebulon Pike leads an expedition from Fort Bellefontaine to explore the west.
Francis II, the last Holy Roman Emperor, abdicates, thus ending the Holy Roman Empire after about a millennium.
September ampampndash France invades Prussia. Prussia declares war on France, and is joined by Saxony and other minor German states.
The Lewis and Clark Expedition reaches St. Louis, Missouri, ending a successful exploration of the Louisiana Territory and the Pacific Northwest.
Battle of Jena-Auerstädt: Napoleon defeats the Prussian army of Prince Hohenlohe at Jena while Marshal Davout defeats the main Prussian army under the Duke of Brunswick, who is killed.
Emperor Jacques I of Haiti (Jean-Jacques Dessalines) is assassinated at the Pont-Rouge, Haiti, and Alexandre Pétion becomes first President of the Republic of Haiti.
French forces enter Berlin.
November ampampndash Napoleon declares a Continental Blockade against the British.

Pike expedition: During his second exploratory expedition, Lieutenant Zebulon Pike sees a distant mountain peak while near the Colorado foothills of the Rocky Mountains (later named Pikes Peak in his honor).
The last major Prussian field force, under Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher, surrenders to the French near Lübeck. Frederick William III has by this time fled to Russia.
French troops enter Warsaw.

1806 Battles of Pultusk and Golymin. Battle of Pultusk: Russian forces under General Bennigsen narrowly escape from a direct confrontation with Napoleon, who goes into winter quarters. Battle of Golymin: Russian forces under General Golitsyn fight a successful rearguard action against French forces under Marshall Murat.
Battle of Eylau: Napoléon's French Empire begins fighting against Russian and Prussian forces of the Fourth Coalition.
Battle of Eylau: Napoleon fights a hard, but inconclusive battle against the Russians under Bennigsen.
The United States Coast Survey is established work begins on August 3, 1816.
Henry Christopher is elected first President of the State of Haiti, ruling the northern part of the country.
In Alabama, former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr is tried for conspiracy and acquitted.

The U.S. Congress passes an act to quotprohibit the importation of slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States ... from any foreign kingdom, place, or countryquot (to take effect 1 January 1808).
The Slave Trade Act becomes law, abolishing the slave trade in the British Empire. (Slavery is abolished in 1833).
The Swansea and Mumbles Railway in South Wales, at this time known as the Oystermouth Railway, becomes the first passenger carrying railway in the world.
H. W. Olbers discovers the asteroid Vesta.
French forces capture Danzig after a 6-week siege.
A grand jury indicts former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr for treason.
June ampampndash Chesapeake-Leopard Affair: The British warship ''HMS Leopard'' captures and boards the ''USS Chesapeake''.
An earthquake strikes Lisbon, Portugal.
The Duke of Portland wins the United Kingdom general election.
Battle of Friedland: Napoleon decisively defeats Bennigsen's Russian army.
A disastrous British attack is mounted against Buenos Aires during the second failed invasion of the Río de la Plata.

July 9 ampndash The Peace of Tilsit is signed between France, Prussia and Russia. Napoleon and Russian Emperor Alexander I ally together against the British. The Prussians are forced to cede more than half their territory, which is formed into the Duchy of Warsaw in their former Polish lands and the Kingdom of Westphalia in western Germany.
With the death of Henry Benedict Stuart, the last Stuart claimant to the throne of the United Kingdom, the movement of Jacobitism comes to an effective end.

Nicéphore Niépce was awarded a patent by Napoleon Bonaparte for the Pyréolophore, the world's first internal combustion engine, after it successfully powered a boat upstream on the river Saône in France.
The ''Clermont'', Robert Fulton's first American steamboat, leaves New York City for Albany, New York on the Hudson River, inaugurating the first commercial steamboat service in the world.
Former U.S. Vice President Aaron Burr is acquitted of treason. He had been accused of plotting to annex parts of Louisiana and Mexico to become part of an independent republic.

September 7 ampndash Battle of Copenhagen: The Royal Navy bombards Copenhagen with fire bombs and phosphorus rockets to prevent Denmark from surrendering its fleet to Napoleon 30% of the city is destroyed and 2,000 citizens are killed.
Robert Morrison, the first Protestant missionary to China, arrives in Guangzhou.
Serfdom is abolished in Prussia by law.
Geological Society of London founded.
The Portuguese Queen Maria I and the Court embark at Lisbon bound for Brazil. Rio de Janeiro becomes the Portuguese capital.
The U.S. Congress passes the Embargo Act.

The importation of slaves into the United States is banned by the Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves this is also the earliest day under the United States Constitution that an amendment can be made restricting slavery.
The organizational meeting leading to the creation of the Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is held in Edinburgh.
The Bragança Portuguese Royal Family arrives in Brazil, running away from the French army.

26 January ampampndash Rum Rebellion: On the 20th anniversary of the foundation of the colony of New South Wales, disgruntled military officers of the New South Wales Corps (the ''Rum Corps'') overthrow and imprison Governor William Bligh and seize control of the colony.
February ampampndash Russia issues an ultimatum to Sweden to join Napoleon's Continental System against Great Britain and Ireland.
French troops occupy the Papal States (Vatican).
The ship ''Topaz'' (from Boston April 5, 1807 hunting seals) rediscovers the Pitcairn Islands only one HMS ''Bounty'' mutineer is still alive, Alexander Smith (John Adams).
Anthracite coal is first burned as residential heating fuel by Jesse Fell in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania.
Finnish War: Russian troops cross the border into Finland without a declaration of war.
Russian troops occupy Helsinki and threaten Sveaborg.
The inaugural meeting of the Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is held in Edinburgh.
Brazil: With the arrival of the Portuguese royal family in Brazil (1808), the colony became the seat of Portuguese Empire.
Russian troops occupy Tampere.
Upon the death of Christian VII, Frederick VI becomes king of Denmark. The next day (March 14), Denmark declares war on Sweden.
Russian troops occupy Turku.
Charles IV of Spain abdicates in favor of his son, Ferdinand VII.

A volcano erupts from an unknown location in the western Pacific.  This causes a localized drop in marine air temperatures during this year, and a world-wide drop in marine air temperature for the following decade.ampamp Chenoweth, M. (2001), Two major volcanic cooling episodes derived from global marine air temperature, AD 1807–1827, Geophys. Res. Lett., 28(15), 2963–2966, doi:10.1029/2000GL012648. ampamp
John Jacob Astor incorporates the American Fur Company.
Troops under colonel Carl von Döbeln clash with Russian troops in Pyhäjoki, Finland.
Peninsular War: The people of Madrid rise up against the French troops.
Finnish War: The fortress of Sveaborg is lost by Sweden to Russia.
Peninsular War: The Madrid rebels who rose on May 2 are executed near Príncipe Pío Hill (Francisco Goya paints the fight and the execution in 1814).
Finnish War: A landing of Swedish troops at Ala-Lemu, near Turku, fails.
Finnish War: A second landing of Swedish troops at Ala-Lemu fails.
Troops under Colonel Adlercreutz force the Russians to withdraw in Lapua.
French General Dupont surrenders to Spanish irregular forces following the Battle of Bailén.
Troops under Carl von Döbeln defeat a Russian attack in Kauhajoki.
August 21  ampndash Battle of Vimiero: British troops under Duke of Wellington defeat the French under General Junot.
The Congress of Erfurt between the emperors Napoleon I of France and Alexander I of Russia starts.
A truce is declared between Swedish and Russian troops in Finland it ends on October 19.
Mahmud II (1808–1839) succeeds Mustafa IV (1807–1808) as  sultan of the Ottoman Empire.
A new truce ends fighting in Finland.
Battle of Tudela: French Marshal Lannes defeats a Spanish army.
November
Swedish troops evacuate Finland. Tsar Alexander I of Russia proclaims Finland a part of Russia.
James Madison defeats Charles C. Pinckney in the U.S. presidential election.
December ampampndash Napoleon joins his army in Spain.
At 20:34 UTC Mercury occults Saturn (there are no observation records).
The original Covent Garden Theatre in London is destroyed by a fire, along with most of the scenery, costumes and scripts.

Ludwig van Beethoven conducts and performs in concert at the Theater an der Wien, Vienna, with the premiere of his ''Fifth Symphony'', ''Sixth Symphony'', ''Fourth Piano Concerto'' (performed by Beethoven himself) and ''Choral Fantasy'' (with Beethoven at the piano).
The Treaty of the Dardanelles between the United Kingdom and the Ottoman Empire is concluded.
Peninsular War: French Marshal Jean Lannes begins the Siege of Zaragoza.
Peninsular War: Battle of Corunna: The French are defeated by the British.
The Illinois Territory is created.
Franz I of Austria declares war on France.
Robert Fulton patents the steamboat in the United States.
Miami University (Ohio) is established on the township of land required to be set aside for it under the conditions of the Miami Purchase in 1794.
A decision by the Supreme Court of the United States states that the power of the federal government is greater than any individual state.
The Siege of Zaragoza grinds to a halt as Jose Palafox surrenders. Over 60,000 have been killed on both sides in 41 days of street fighting.
Battle of Valls: Spanish forces are defeated in Catalonia by Marshal Laurent Gouvion Saint-Cyr.
Embargo Act of 1807 is repealed in the United States the Non-Intercourse Act replaces it.
James Madison succeeds Thomas Jefferson as the President of the United States.
A military coup ousts Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden he is confined in Gripsholm Castle.

At the Diet of Porvoo, Finland's four Estates pledge allegiance to Alexander I of Russia, commencing the secession of the future Grand Principality of Finland from Sweden. The Emperor in return, promises to retain and uphold former laws and privileges as well as the dominant Lutheran religion. His pledge is later interpreted by the Finns as a confirmation of constitutional laws, which had, effectively, established Finland as a separate state in real union with the Russia.
King Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden abdicates and is later exiled.
Peninsular War
First Battle of Porto: 18,000 Portuguese soldiers are drowned in a rout after defeat by the French under Marshal Soult.
Battle of Medellín at Extremadura: massive Spanish casualties in a rout by French cavalry under Marshal Victor.
Tiroleans rise under the command of Andreas Hofer against French and Bavarian occupation.
Battle of Abensberg, Bavaria: Napoleon I defeats Austria.
Battle of Raszyn: The armies of Austria are defeated by the Duchy of Warsaw as a part of the struggles of the Fifth Coalition .
Battle of Eckmühl: French troops under Napoleon I and Marshal Davout defeat the Austrians under Archduke Charles.
Mary Kies is the first American woman to be awarded a patent.
The Swiss canton of Aargau denies Jews citizenship.
Gustav IV Adolf is officially deposed from the Swedish throne by the Riksdag of the Estates.
Napoleon I of France orders the annexation of the Papal States to the French Empire. When he announces that the Pope's secular power has ended, the Pope excommunicates him.
Battle of Aspern-Essling: Austrian troops under Archduke Karl beat the French under Napoleon in a hard fought battle.

Sweden promulgates a new Instrument of Government, which restores political power to the Riksdag of the Estates after authoritarian rule since 1772. On the same day, Duke Charles (uncle of the deposed king Gustav IV Adolf) is elected King under the name Charles XIII.
Shoja Shah of Afghanistan signs a treaty with the British. Only weeks later, he is succeeded by Mahmud Shah.
July 6 ampndash Battle of Wagram: Napoleon defeats the Austrians.
French troops arrest Pope Pius VII and take him to Liguria.
French Marshal Marmont engages in the inconclusive Battle of Znaim against the Austrians.

The city of La Paz (current Bolivia) declares its independence from the Spanish Crown and forms the ''Junta Tuitiva'', the first independent government in Spanish America, led by Pedro Domingo Murillo.
Walcheren Campaign: A British invasion army lands on Walcheren.
Seventy disciples of Vilna Gaon arrive in Palestine.
Ecuador declares independence from Spain.
Severe earthquakes strike the Azores and the village of São Miguel sinks.
Battle of Almonacid de Toledo: A poorly led Spanish army is defeated by King Joseph Bonaparte's French army.
The Peace of Hamina is signed between Russia and Sweden in the Finnish War. The territory to become the Grand Principality of Finland is ceded to Russia by the Treaty of Fredrikshamn.
A new theatre to hold the Royal Opera House opens in London to replace the first, burnt down in a fire in 1808. The price increases lead to the Old Price Riots which last for 64 days.
Prince Klemens von Metternich becomes Austrian foreign minister.
Along the Natchez Trace in Tennessee, explorer Meriwether Lewis dies under mysterious circumstances at an inn called Grinder's Stand.
The Treaty of Schoenbrunn cedes the Illyrian provinces to France.
Berners Street Hoax: Theodore Hook manages to attract dozens of people to 54 Berners Street in London.
Battle of Ocana: A Spanish army is ridden down and 20,000 are killed by French forces.
Benjamin Bathurst, a British diplomat, mysteriously disappears (possibly murdered) in Perleberg, west of Berlin.
A British invasion force leaves Vlissingen.
Wearing masks at balls is forbidden in Boston, Massachusetts.
Australian seal hunter Frederick Hasselborough discovers Campbell Island in the subantarctic.
The marriage of Napoleon and Josephine is annulled.
Tyrolean rebel leader Andreas Hofer is executed.
Peninsular War: The French Army, under the command of André Masséna, retreats from Portugal.
Napoleon marries Marie-Louise of Austria.
Venezuela achieves home rule: Vicente Emparán, Governor of the Captaincy General, is removed by the people of Caracas and a junta is installed.
April through Summer ampampndash Kingdom of Hawaii unified.
Beethoven composes his famous piano piece, ''Für Elise''.
Macon's Bill Number 2 becomes law in the United States, intending to motivate Britain and France to stop seizing American vessels during the Napoleonic Wars.

May 25 ampndash May Revolution: Armed citizens of Buenos Aires expel the Viceroy and establish a provincial government for Argentina, the first South American state to proclaim independence from Spain.
The Society in Dedham for Apprehending Horse Thieves is founded in Dedham, Massachusetts.
John Jacob Astor forms the Pacific Fur Company.

June ampampndash Nicolas Appert publishes ''L'art de conserver pendant plusieurs années toutes les substances animales ou végétales'', the first description of modern food preservation using airtight containers.
Napoleon annexes the Kingdom of Holland.
Frederick Hasselborough discovers Macquarie Island in the subantarctic.
Colombia declares its independence from the Spanish Empire.
The city of Santa Cruz de Mompox, in modern-day Colombia, declares independence from the Spanish Empire.
Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte, Marshal of France, is elected Crown Prince of Sweden by the Swedish Riksdag of the Estates.

The ''Tonquin'' sets sail from New York Harbor with 33 employees of John Jacob Astor's newly created Pacific Fur Company on board. After a 6-month journey around the tip of South America, the ship arrives at the mouth of the Columbia River and Astor's men establish the fur-trading town of Astoria.
''Grito de Dolores'': Miguel Hidalgo, a Catholic priest from Guanajuato, incites the revolt that becomes the Mexican War of Independence.
Chile forms its First National Junta, which is the country's first step towards its independence.
The Republic of West Florida declares independence from Spain.
A new Act of Succession is adopted by the Riksdag of the Estates and Jean Baptiste Bernadotte becomes heir to the Swedish throne.
First Oktoberfest: The Bavarian royalty invites the citizens of Munich to join the celebration of the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig of Bavaria to Princess Therese of Saxe-Hildburghausen.
The United States annexes the Republic of West Florida.
Anglo-Swedish War (1810–1812): Sweden declares war on the United Kingdom.
An unsuccessful slave revolt is led by Charles Deslandes in St. Charles and St. James, Louisiana.
The Casas Revolt begins in San Antonio, Texas.
British Regency: George, Prince of Wales becomes Prince Regent because of the perceived insanity of his father, King George III of the United Kingdom.
Citadel Massacre in Cairo: Egyptian ruler Mohammed Ali kills the last Mamluk leaders.
Peninsular War: Battle of Barrosa, an unsuccessful French attack on a larger Anglo-Portuguese-Spanish force attempting to lift the Siege of Cádiz in Spain.
Battle of Lissa: The British fleet defeats the French.
The Commissioners' Plan for Manhattan is presented.
Great Comet discovered by Honoré Flaugergues.
Battle of Anholt: The British Navy defeats Denmark.
Henri Christophe is proclaimed King Henri I, turning the northern State of Haiti into the Kingdom of Haiti.
April 6 ampndash Revolutionary riots occur in Buenos Aires.
Paraguay declares independence from Spain.
Battle of Albuera: Spain, Portugal and Great Britain defeat the French.
The Battle of Las Piedras is fought near Las Piedras, Banda Oriental, resulting in the first victory for the independentists of Uruguay.
The Great fire of the Podil breaks out in Kiev, Ukraine.
Venezuela becomes the first South American country to gain independence from Spain.
Venezuela declares its independence from Spain.
Italian scientist Amedeo Avogadro publishes his memoire about the molecular content of gases.
ampampampmdash David Thompson reaches the mouth of the Columbia River, finding Fort Astoria under construction.
ampampampmdash Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla is executed as a rebel by the Spanish government of New Spain.
First ascent of Jungfrau, third highest summit in the Bernese Alps,
September ampampndash Nathan of Breslov leads the first annual Rosh Hashana kibbutz (pilgrimage) of Breslov Hasidim to the grave of Rabbi Nachman of Breslov in Uman, Ukraine.
Inventor John Stevens' boat, the ''Juliana'', begins operation as the first steam-powered ferry service, between New York City and Hoboken, New Jersey.
José Gervasio Artigas and 16.000 ''orientales'' leave the Banda Oriental del Uruguay to go into exile.
The Argentine Government declares freedom of expression for the press.
November ampampndash Luddite uprisings begin in northern England and the Midlands.
Battle of Tippecanoe: American troops led by William Henry Harrison defeat the Native American chief Tecumseh.
José Miguel Carrera, Chilean founding father, is sworn in as President of the executive Junta of the government of Chile.
The New Madrid earthquake in the Mississippi Valley near New Madrid reverses the course of the river for a while. Other earthquakes along the fault occur on January 23, 1812 and February 7, 1812.
First Constitution of Republic of Venezuela after declares its independence from Spain.
The ''Allgemeines bürgerliches Gesetzbuch'' (the Austrian civil code) enters into force in the Austrian Empire.
The last New Madrid Earthquake strikes New Madrid, Missouri, with an estimated moment magnitude of over 8
Massachusetts governor Elbridge Gerry invents gerrymandering.
Napoleon authorizes the usage of ''Mesures usuelles'', the basis of the Metric System.
First Chilean newspaper La Aurora de Chile is dealing with political philosophy and standing in favor of the new national government.
Poet Lord Byron gives his first address as a member of the House of Lords, in defense of Luddite violence against Industrialism in his home county of Nottinghamshire.
Luddites attack the wool processing factory of Frank Vickerman in West Yorkshire.
The Cádiz Cortes, in exile, create the first modern Spanish constitution.
An earthquake destroys Caracas, Venezuela.
U.S. President James Madison enacts a 90-day embargo on trade with the United Kingdom.
Louisiana is admitted as the 18th U.S. state.
John Bellingham assassinates British Prime Minister Spencer Perceval in the lobby of the British House of Commons.
Russian Field Marshal Mikhail Kutuzov signs the Treaty of Bucharest, ending the Russo-Turkish War, 1806-1812. Bessarabia is illegitimately annexed by Imperial Russia.
Felling mine disaster: A mine explosion at the Felling colliery near Jarrow, England leaves 96 dead.
War of 1812: U.S. President James Madison asks the U.S. Congress to declare war on the United Kingdom.
Following Louisiana's admittance as a U.S. state, the territory by that name is renamed the Missouri Territory.
New York State charters City Bank of New York, which later became Citibank.
The War of 1812 begins between the United States and the British Empire.
Napoleon's Grande Armée crosses the Niemen River and invades Russia (see French invasion of Russia).
Americans invade Canada at Windsor, Ontario.
Russia's Patriotic War ampndash Battle of Klyastitsy: Kulnev defeats Oudinot but sustains a mortal wound.
Peninsular War ampndash Battle of Salamanca: British forces led by Lord Wellington defeat French troops near Salamanca in Spain.
War of 1812: Tecumseh's Indian force ambushes Thomas Van Horne's 200 Americans at Brownstone Creek, causing them to flee and retreat.
Peninsular War: The combined English and Portuguese army under the command of Wellington enters Madrid following the Battle of Salamanca.
War of 1812: American General William Hull surrenders Fort Detroit without a fight to the British Army.

War of 1812: The ''USS Constitution'' defeats the British frigate ''Guerrière'' off the coast of Nova Scotia. The British shot is said to have bounced off the ''Constitution'''s sides, earning her the nickname quotOld Ironsidesquot.
Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Borodino: The bloodiest battle of the Napoleonic wars ends in a tactical victory for Napoleon.
Napoleon's troops enter Moscow, which is deliberately set on fire by Muscovites on orders of Fyodor Rostopchin.
October ampampndash The capital of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, United States is permanently moved from Lancaster to Harrisburg.
War of 1812: American naval forces under Lieutenant Jesse Duncan Elliott capture two British warships, {{HMS|Detroit|1812|6}} and HMS ''Caledonia''.

War of 1812 ampndash Battle of Queenston Heights: As part of the Niagara campaign in Ontario, Canada, United States forces under General Stephen Van Rensselaer are repulsed from invading Canada by British and native troops led by Sir Isaac Brock  (he dies during the battle).
October 20 ampndash Second Battle of Polotsk ampndash Russia
Napoleon begins his retreat from Moscow.

Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Maloyaroslavets: An inconclusive encounter between the French vanguard and a Russian force leads Napoleon to decide to retreat along the same line as his advance, with disastrous results.
James Madison defeats DeWitt Clinton in the U.S. presidential election.
Napoleonic Wars ampndash Battle of Vyazma: Napoleon's retreating army is defeated.
A general election in the United Kingdom sees victory for the Tory Party under Robert Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool.
The first volume of Grimm's Fairy Tales is published.
War of 1812: The USS ''Constitution'' defeats the British frigate ''Java'' off the coast of Brazil.
Convention of Tauroggen is signed.
The Philharmonic Society founded in London (later the Royal Philharmonic Society).
Jane Austen's ''Pride and Prejudice'' is published.
Fort Meigs: Leftwich is not successful, and when he leaves, Major Amos Stoddard assumes the command of the post.

February ampampndash General Harrison sends out an expedition to burn the British vessels at Fort Malden by going across Lake Erie via the Bass Islands in sleighs, but the ice is not hard enough and the expedition returns.
James Madison is sworn in as President of the United States, for his second term.
Mexican War of Independence ampndash Battle of Rosillo Creek: The Republican Army of the North defeats the Spanish Royalist Army in present-day Bexar County, Texas.
Colonel James Ball arrives at Fort Meigs with 200 dragoons.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of York: United States troops raid, destroy, but do not hold the capital of Ontario, York (present day Toronto, Ontario).
Battle of Lützen: Napoleon wins against the German alliance.
Gregory Blaxland, William Lawson and William Wentworth leave on an expedition to cross the Blue Mountains.
May 21 ampndash Battle of Bautzen: Napoleon again defeats his combined enemies.
War of 1812: In Canada, American forces capture Fort George.
War of 1812 ampampndash Battle of Stoney Creek: A British force of 700 under John Vincent defeat an American force three times its size under William Winder and John Chandler.
Gregory Blaxland, William Lawson and William Wentworth succeed in crossing the Blue Mountains and return home.
Peninsular War ampndash Battle of Vitoria: A British, Spanish, and Portuguese force of 78,000 with 96 guns under Wellington defeats a French force of 58,000 with 153 guns under Joseph Bonaparte.
War of 1812: Three weeks of British raids on Fort Schlosser, Black Rock and Plattsburgh, New York begin.
The Carabinieri, the national military police of Italy, are founded by Victor Emmanuel I as the police force of the Kingdom of Sardinia.
Missionaries Adoniram Judson and his wife Ann Hasseltine Judson arrive in Burma.
Gervasio Antonio de Posadas joins Argentina's second triumvirate.
Battle of Großbeeren: Napoleon is defeated by Prussia and Sweden.
Battle of Katzbach: Napoleon's troops are defeated by Prussia and Russia.
27 ampndash Battle of Dresden: Napoleon's troops are victorious.
30 ampndash Battle of Kulm: Napoleon's troops are defeated by Russia, Prussia and Austria.
After besieging San Sebastian, allied troops of Spain rampage, ransack and burn down the town almost entirely.
September ampampndash Robert Southey becomes Poet Laureate of Britain.
Battle of Dennewitz: The armies of Napoleon are again defeated by Prussia and Russia.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of Lake Erie: An American squadron under Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry defeats a British squadron, capturing 6 ships.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of the Thames in Upper Canada: William Henry Harrison defeats the British, and native leader Tecumseh is killed in battle.
After a ceremony in Caracas, Venezuela, the municipality gives Simón Bolívar the title of ''El Libertador''.
October 19 ampndash Battle of Leipzig: Napoleon is defeated.

November 5 ampndash Persia and Russia sign the Treaty of Gulistan of 1813 at the end of the Russo-Persian War by which Persia (Iran) loses all its territories to the north of Aras River to the Russians.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of Chateauguay: Charles de Salaberry defeats an American invasion
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of Crysler's Farm: the Americans are defeated by the British.
An independent government is restored in the Netherlands.
December 19 ampndash War of 1812:  British soldiers and native allies invade the United States and are successful in the Capture of Fort Niagara and attack Lewiston, New York.
War of 1812: British soldiers burn Buffalo, New York.
Denmark cedes Norway to Sweden in exchange for west Pomerania, as part of the Treaty of Kiel.
Battle of Brienne: Emperor Napoleon I of France is victorious against von Blücher.
Gervasio Antonio de Posadas becomes Supreme Director of Argentina.
February ampampndash George Hamilton-Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen, represents Britain at the Congress of Chatillon.
Lord Byron's semi-autobiographical tale in verse ''The Corsair'' is published by John Murray in London and sells 10,000 copies on this day.
Norway's independence is proclaimed, marking the ultimate end of the Kalmar Union.
A fire destroys the Custom House, London.
Battle of Vauchamps: Napoleon I of France is victorious against von Blücher.
Battle of Montereau: Napoleon is victorious against Austrian forces.
Great Stock Exchange Fraud in London.
Battle of Craonne: Napoleon is victorious against von Blücher.
The USS Enterprise reaches Wilmington, North Carolina, returning from the Caribbean.
Battle of Laon: von Blücher defeats Napoleon.
Louis-Antoine, Duke of Angoulême enters Bordeaux, marking the restoration of the Bourbon dynasty.
De Nederlandsche Bank is established.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of Horseshoe Bend: In northern Alabama, United States forces under General Andrew Jackson defeat the Creek Indians.
Napoleonic Wars: Sixth Coalition forces march into Paris.
Anti-Napoleonic troops occupy Paris.
Bourbon Restoration: Louis XVIII is invited to occupy the restored French throne.
The Duke of Wellington wins the Battle of Toulouse.
Napoleon abdicates unconditionally as Emperor of the French.
The Royal Norwegian Navy is re-established.
The Duke of Provence, the future Louis XVIII of France, returns to Paris.
British-American War (War of 1812): The British attack Fort Ontario at Oswego, New York.
The Constitution of Norway is signed and the Danish Crown Prince Christian Frederik is elected King of Norway by the Norwegian Constituent Assembly.
The occupation of Monaco changes from French to Austrian hands.
The First Treaty of Paris is signed returning France's borders to their 1792 extent. Napoleon is exiled to Elba on the same day.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of Chippawa: American Major General Jacob Brown defeats British General Phineas Riall at Chippawa, Ontario.
War of 1812: General Phineas Riall advances toward Niagara Falls, Ontario to halt Jacob Brown's American invaders.
George Stephenson tests his first locomotive ''Blucher'' successfully in England.

War of 1812 ampampndash Battle of Lundy's Lane: Reinforcements arrive near Niagara Falls, Ontario for General Riall's British and Canadian force, and a bloody, all-night battle with Jacob Brown's Americans commences at 1800ampampnbsphours Americans retreat to Fort Erie.
Pope Pius VII decrees the bull Sollicitudo omnium ecclesiarum reestablishing the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) all over the world, after having approved their survival and existence in Russia.
In England, the last hanging under the Black Act is carried out, of William Potter for cutting down an orchard (although the judge petitioned for reprieve).
The Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1814 is signed.
War of 1812: British troops occupy Washington, D.C., setting numerous buildings on fire, including the Capitol.
Alexandria, Virginia, offers surrender to the British fleet without a fight.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of Lake Champlain: An American squadron under Thomas Macdonough defeats the British squadron, ultimately forcing the invading army to retreat back into Canada.

War of 1812: The British bombard Fort McHenry at Baltimore. The British failure at the Battle of Baltimore is a turning point in the war, and the American defense of the fort inspires Francis Scott Key to compose the poem later set to music as ''The Star-Spangled Banner''.
London Beer Flood: A large vat full of porter (beer) owned by Meux's Brewery of London bursts, demolishing buildings and killing nine.
War of 1812: Andrew Jackson seizes Pensacola, Florida.
November ampampndash Congress of Vienna: The settling of the many issues arising from the French Revolutionary Wars, the Napoleonic Wars, and the dissolution of the Holy Roman Empire.
The Hartford Convention is convened by members of the American Federalist Party.
War of 1812: The Treaty of Ghent is signed, officially ending the war.
Samuel Marsden of the Church Missionary Society preaches the first sermon in New Zealand at Oihi
Lord Byron marries Anna Isabella Milbanke in Seaham, County Durham.
Austria, Britain, and Bourbon-restored France form a secret defensive alliance treaty against Prussia and Russia.
War of 1812 ampndash Battle of New Orleans: American forces under General Andrew Jackson defeat an invading British force.
February ampampndash The Hartford Convention arrives in Washington DC.
The first commercial cheese factory is founded in Switzerland.
The first Dutch student association, the Groninger Studenten Corps, Vindicat atque Polit is founded in the Netherlands. The first rector of the senate was B.J. Winter.
New Jersey grants the first American railroad charter to a John Stevens.
The  Spanish reconquest of Latin America begins.
The War of 1812 between the United States, Canada and the British Empire ends.
Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from Elba.
Napoleon returns to France from his banishment on Elba.
March 18 ampndash The last King of Ceylon, Sri Vikrama Rajasinha is deposed under the terms of the Kandyan Convention, which results in Ceylon becoming a British colony.
The first student association in the Netherlands, Vindicat atque Polit, has its first fraternity, Mutua Fides, opened.
Joachim Murat, King of Naples declares war on Austria in an attempt to save his throne, starting the Neapolitan War.
William I becomes King of the Netherlands.
Napoleon enters Paris after escaping from Elba with a regular army of 140,000 and a volunteer force of around 200,000 beginning his quotHundred Daysquot rule.

The Second Serbian Uprising against Ottoman rule takes place in Takovo, Serbia. By the end of the year Serbia is acknowledged as a semi-independent state the ideals of the First Serbian Uprising have thus been temporarily achieved.
Battle of Tolentino: Austria defeats the Kingdom of Naples, which quickly ends the Neapolitan War. Joachim Murat, the defeated King of Naples, is forced to flee to Corsica and is later executed.
The ''Arniston'', an East Indiaman repatriating wounded troops to England from Ceylon, is wrecked near Waenhuiskrans, South Africa with the loss of 372 of the 378 people on board.
Final Act of the Congress of Vienna is signed: A new European political situation is set. The German Confederation is created and the neutrality of Switzerland is guaranteed.
Battle of Ligny: Napoleon defeats a Prussian army under Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher.
Battle of Quatre Bras: Marshal Ney wins a strategic victory over an Anglo-Dutch force.
Battle of Waterloo: The Duke of Wellington decisively defeats Napoleon.
Napoleon abdicates again Napoleon II (1811–1832), age 4, rules for two weeks (22 June to 7 July).

Louis XVIII returns to Paris, and is 'restored' as King of France (he had declared himself king on 8 June 1795, at the death of his nephew, 10-year-old Louis XVII, and had lived in Westphalia, Verona, Russia, and England).
Napoleon boards {{HMS|Bellerophon|1786|6}} off Rochefort and surrenders to Captain Frederick Lewis Maitland of the Royal Navy.
September ampampndash Austria, Prussia and Russia sign a Holy Alliance to uphold the European status quo.
The Great September Gale of 1815 is the first hurricane to strike New England in 180 years.

October ampampndash Robert Adams, American sailor and first white man to visit Timbuktu, was found wandering the streets of London, starving and half-naked. His discovery was significant because it led to the invitation for him to tell his story as a Barbary captive, which later was published as ''The Narrative of Robert Adams''.ampamp{{cite book|last=Adams|first=Charles Hansford|title=The Narrative of Robert Adams: A Barbary Captive|year=2005|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|pages=x}}ampamp
The Chassigny Mars meteorite falls in Chassigny, Haute-Marne, France.
Napoleon begins his exile on Saint Helena in the Atlantic Ocean.
Humphry Davy patents the miner's safety lamp for use in coal mining.
Tsar Alexander I of Russia signs an order for the expulsion of the Jesuits from the Russian Empire.
Sir Humphry Davy tests the Davy lamp for miners at Hebburn Colliery.
Fire nearly destroys the city of St. John's, Newfoundland.
Estonia emancipates its peasants from serfdom.
