Friedrich Karl Ludwig, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Beck dies and is succeeded by the later Friedrich Wilhelm, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg, his son and founder of the Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg.
Gioachino Rossini's opera ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' premieres at the Teatro Argentina in Rome.
The Second Bank of the United States obtains its charter.
In Philadelphia, the African Methodist Episcopal Church is established by Richard Allen and other African-American Methodists, the first such denomination completely independent of White churches.
Leopold of Saxe-Coburg (later King of the Belgians) marries Charlotte Augusta, but she dies the next year.
Battle of Seven Oaks: The Hudson's Bay Company is defeated by the North West Company, near Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada.

July ampampndash Lord Byron, Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin, Percy Bysshe Shelley and John Polidori, gathered at the Villa Diodati by Lake Geneva in a rainy Switzerland, tell each other tales. This gives rise to two classic Gothic narratives, Mary Shelley's ''Frankenstein'' and Polidori's ''The Vampyre''.
Argentina declares independence from Spain.
The French passenger ship ''Medusa'' runs aground off the coast of Senegal, with 140 lives lost in the botched rescue that takes weeks, leading to a scandal in the French government.
The Treaty of St. Louis is signed in St. Louis, Missouri.
Bombardment of Algiers: Various European Allies ships force the Dey of Algiers to free Christian slaves.
Penang Free School was founded by Rev. Sparke Hutchings on the island of Penang, Malaysia.
James Monroe defeats Rufus King in the U.S. presidential election.
Indiana is admitted as the 19th U.S. state.
Merger of the thrones of  Sicily and  Naples into the throne of  the Two Sicilies under Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies.
American Colonization Society established.
An army of 5,423 soldiers, led by General José de San Martín, starts crossing the Andes from Argentina to liberate Chile and then Peru.
Rammohun Roy and David Hare found Hindu College in Kolkata, offering instructions in Western languages and subjects.
Battle of Chacabuco: The Argentine/Chilean patriotic army defeats the Spanish.
President James Madison vetoes John C. Calhoun's Bonus Bill.
James Monroe succeeds James Madison as President of the United States of America.
April ampampndash An earthquake strikes Palermo, Italy.
Princess Caraboo appears in Almondsbury in Gloucestershire, England.
The American School for the Deaf opens in Hartford, Connecticut.
The Rush-Bagot Treaty is signed.
May ampampndash The General Convention of the Episcopal Church founds the General Theological Seminary while meeting in New York City.
A large riot breaks out in Copenhagen Prison the army is sent to quell it.
At Rome, New York, construction on the Erie Canal begins.
The town of Araraquara, Brazil is founded.
An earthquake near the site of the ancient Greek city of Helike results in 65 deaths.
Emperor Ninkō accedes to the throne of Japan.
Third Anglo-Maratha War breaks out with the Battle of Khadki.
The first Seminole War begins in Florida.
Frédéric Cailliaud discovers the old Roman emerald mines at Sikait, Egypt.
Mary Shelley's ''Frankenstein'' is published.
21:52 UTC) ampndash Venus occults Jupiter. It is the last occultation of one planet by another before November 22, 2065.

Treaty of Mandeswar brings an end to the Third Anglo-Maratha War, ending the dominance of Marathas, and enhancing the power of the British East India Company, which controls territory occupied by 180 million Indians.
Upon his death, King Charles XIII of Sweden (Charles II of Norway) is succeeded on both thrones by his adoptive son Charles XIV/III John, starting the Royal House of Bernadotte.
Chile proclaims its independence from Spain.
First Seminole War: General Andrew Jackson and his American army invade Florida.
Easter Day in Western Christianity falls on its earliest possible date. In Western Christianity, it will not occur on this date again until 2285.

The U.S. Congress adopts the flag of the United States as having thirteen red and white stripes and one star for each state (twenty) with additional stars to be added whenever a new state is added to the Union.

Brooks Brothers, the oldest men's clothier in the United States, opens its first store on the northeast corner of Catherine and Cherry Streets in New York City, where the South Street Seaport now stands.
August 9 ampndash U.S. Survey of the Coast operations suspended.
Charles XIV of Sweden-Norway is crowned king of Sweden.
Separate Topographical Bureau of the US War Department.
Carl III of Sweden-Norway is crowned king of Norway, in Trondheim.
Border markers are formally installed for the European territory of Moresnet.
Claudine Thévenet (known as 'Mary of St. Ignatius') founds the Roman Catholic order ''Religieuses de Jésus-Marie'' (quotReligious of Jesus And Maryquot) in Lyon, France.

Treaty between the U.S. and the United Kingdom establishes the boundary between the U.S. and British North America as the 49th parallel from the Lake of the Woods to the Rocky Mountains, also creating the Northwest Angle.
Anglo-Chinese College is founded by Robert Morrison in Malacca (later renamed Ying Wa College).
The Saint Louis Academy, which later becomes Saint Louis University, is founded by Reverend Louis William Valentine Dubourg.
Illinois is admitted as the 21st U.S. state.
''Silent Night'' composed by Franz Xaver Gruber and Josef Mohr.
The Panic of 1819, the first major financial crisis in the United States, begins.
Simón Bolívar proclaims the Republic of Gran Colombia.
Thomas Jefferson founds the University of Virginia.
Sir Stamford Raffles lands on the island of Singapore.

The Supreme Court of the United States under John Marshall rules in favor of Dartmouth College in the famous ''Dartmouth College v. Woodward'' case, allowing Dartmouth to keep its charter and remain a private institution.
A formal treaty between Hussein Shah of Johor and the British Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles establishes a trading settlement in Singapore.
The United States House of Representatives agrees to the Tallmadge Amendment barring slaves from the new state of Missouri (the opening vote in a controversy that leads to the Missouri Compromise).

Captain William Smith in British merchant brig ''Williams'' sights Williams Point, the northeast extremity of Livingston Island in the South Shetlands, the first land discovered south of latitude 60° S.
Spain cedes Florida to the United States by the Adams-Onís Treaty in exchange for the American renunciation of any claims on Texas that it might have from the Louisiana Purchase and $5 million.
The U.S. naval vessel USS ''Columbus'' is launched in Washington, DC.
''McCulloch v. Maryland'': The U.S. Supreme Court rules that the Bank of the United States is constitutional.
Burlington Arcade opens in London.

The ''SS Savannah'' leaves port at Savannah, Georgia on a voyage to become the first steamship to cross the Atlantic Ocean, although only a fraction of the trip will be made under steam. The ship arrives at  Liverpool, England on June 20.
Norwich University is founded by Captain Alden Partridge in Vermont as the first private military school in the United States.
Battle of Boyacá: Simón Bolívar is victorious over the Royalist Army in Colombia.
Peterloo Massacre:  The cavalry charges into a crowd of protesters in Manchester, UK, resulting in 11 deaths and over 400 injuries.
The Carlsbad Decree is issued throughout the German Confederation.
Alabama is admitted as the 22nd U.S. state.
Trienio Liberal in Spain: A constitutionalist military insurrection at Cádiz leads to the summoning of the Spanish Parliament (March 7).
Indiana University Bloomington is founded as the Indiana State Seminary (renamed Indiana College, 1846).

George IV of the United Kingdom ascends the throne on the death at Windsor Castle of his father George III (after 59 years on the throne), ending the period known as the British Regency. There will be a gap of 21 years before the title Prince of Wales is next used.
Lord Cochrane occupies Valdivia in the name of the Republic of Chile.
86 free African American colonists sail from New York City to Freetown, Sierra Leone.
Minh Mang starts to rule in Vietnam.
A revolt begins in Santa María Chiquimula, Totonicapán department of Guatemala.
he Daoguang Emperor succeeds the throne of the Qing Dynasty.
The Cato Street conspiracy is exposed in England the principals are executed on May 1.
King Ferdinand VII of Spain accepts the new constitution, beginning the ''Trienio Liberal''.
Maine is admitted as the 23rd U.S. state.
April ampampndash Hans Christian Ørsted discovers the relationship between electricity and magnetism.
A Proclamation, signed quotBy order of the Committee of Organisation for forming a Provisional Governmentquot, begins the quotRadical Warquot in Scotland.
The statue of the Venus de Milo (Aphrodite of Milos, c.150 BC-125 BC) is discovered on the Greek island of Milos by a peasant named Yorgos Kentrotas.
King William I of Württemberg marries his cousin, Pauline Therese, in Stuttgart.
The last hanging, drawing and quartering in Britain is meted out to the Cato Street conspirators for treason (only hanged and beheaded).
{{HMS|Beagle}} (the ship that will later take young Charles Darwin on his scientific voyage) is launched at Woolwich Dockyard.
John Stuart Mill sets out on his formative boyhood trip to France.
July ampampndash A revolt under Guglielmo Pepe forces Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies to sign a constitution modeled on the Spanish Constitution of 1812.

Saint Cronan's Boys National School opens in Bray, Co. Wicklow, Ireland under the title ''Bray Male School''. It is the oldest school in Bray and its notable pupils will include President of Ireland Cearbhall Ó Dálaigh.

Opening of Union Chain Bridge across the River Tweed between England and Scotland, a  wrought iron suspension bridge designed by Captain Samuel Brown. Its span of 449ampnbspft (137 m) is the world's longest for a vehicular bridge at this time.
A Constitutionalist insurrection breaks out at Oporto, Portugal.
Revolution breaks out in Lisbon against John VI of Portugal.
History of Ecuador: Guayaquil declares independence from Spain.
November 20 ampndash The Congress of Troppau (Opava) is convened between the rulers of Russia, Austria and Prussia.

After the sinking of the whaleship ''Essex'' of Nantucket by a whale the survivors are left afloat in three small whaleboats. They eventually resort, by common consent, to cannibalism to allow some to survive.
U.S. presidential election: James Monroe is re-elected, virtually unopposed.
The town of Tuscumbia, Alabama, is incorporated.
Peter I Island in the Antarctic first sighted by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
Alexander Island is first discovered by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
The George Washington University is chartered as The Columbian College of the District of Columbia by President Monroe.
James Monroe is sworn in for his second term as President of the United States.

O.S.)/April 6 (N.S.) ampndash Greece's traditional Independence Day (although more recent historical evidence suggests that the Greek War of Independence against the Ottoman Empire had started before this date).

Ecumenical Patriarch Patriarch Gregory V of Constantinople is blamed by the Ottoman government for being unable to suppress Greek independence and is hung outside the main gate of the Patriarchal Cathedral immediately after the celebration of Easter.
Emperor Napoléon I dies in exile on Saint Helena of stomach cancer.
Establishment of the Peloponnesian Senate by the Greek rebels.
King Badi VII of Sennar surrenders his throne and realm to Ismail Pasha, general of the Ottoman Empire, ending the existence of that Sudanese kingdom.
The Philikí Etaireía are decisively defeated by the Ottomans at Drăgăşani (in Wallachia).
Battle of Carabobo: Simón Bolívar wins Venezuela's independence from Spain.
The New Hampton School is founded in the United States state of New Hampshire.
The United States takes possession of its newly bought territory of Florida from Spain.
George IV is crowned king of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
Peru declares independence from Spain.
Missouri is admitted as the 24th U.S. state (''see'' History of Missouri).
Navarino Massacre: Greek rebels massacre 3,000 inhabitants of the city of Navarino.
Jarvis Island is discovered by the crew of the ''Eliza Frances''.
Chilean general José Miguel Carrera is executed by an Argentinian military tribunal in the city of Mendoza.
The Ukase of 1821: Russia proclames territorial sovereignty over Northwestern North America, now present day Alaska.

The Republic of Gran Colombia (a federation covering much of present day Venezuela, Colombia, Panama, and Ecuador) is established, with Simón Bolívar as the founding President and Francisco de Paula Santander as vice president.
Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica gain independence from Spain.
Amherst College is founded in Massachusetts.
Greek War of Independence: Siege of Tripolitsa ends when Greek rebels massacre all 35,000 Turkish and Jewish inhabitants of Tripoli, Greece.
Mexico gains its independence from Spain following the Mexican War of Independence.
American Old West: The Santa Fe Trail is first used by William Becknell.
Panama declares independence from Spain, joining Gran Colombia (''see'' History of Panama).
The Dominican Republic declares independence from Spain (''see'' History of the Dominican Republic). It will be invaded by Haiti in 1822.
The South Orkney Islands are discovered by George Powell and Nathaniel Palmer.
The Eyjafjallajökull volcano in Iceland begins to erupt.
Chinese junk ''Tek Sing'' sinks in the South China Sea with the loss of around 1600 people on board.
The invading Haitian forces led by Jean Pierre Boyer arrive in Santo Domingo, to overthrow the newly founded Republic.
Greek War of Independence: Start of Chios Massacre, during which 20,000 Greeks on the island of Chios are slaughtered by Ottoman troops and 23,000 exiled.
Battle of Pichincha: Simón Bolívar secures the independence of Quito.
116 people die in the Grue Church fire, the biggest fire disaster in Norway's history.
Alexis St. Martin accidentally shot in the stomach, which leads the way to William Beaumont's studies on digestion.

Charles Babbage publishes a proposal for a quotdifference enginequot, a forerunner of the modern computer for calculating logarithms and trigonometric functions. Construction of an operational version will proceed under British Government sponsorship 1823ampndash32 but it will never be completed.
The Chippewas turn over huge tract of land in Ontario to the United Kingdom.
Greek War of Independence: Greeks defeat Ottoman forces at Thermopylae.
Guayaquil conference: José de San Martín arrives in Guayaquil, Ecuador, to meet with Simón Bolívar.
Guayaquil Conference: Simón Bolívar and General José de San Martín meet in Guayaquil, which Bolívar later annexes.
The last public whipping is carried out in Edinburgh.
St David's College (now the University of Wales, Lampeter) is founded by Thomas Burgess, Bishop of St David's.
29 ampndash Visit of King George IV to Scotland.
The English ship ''Orion'' lands at Yerba Buena, now named San Francisco, under the command of William A. Richardson.
Brazilian independence: Brazil declares its independence from Portugal.
George Canning is appointed British Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.
Constituent Congress of Peru begins its first session.
Portugal approves its first Constitution.
Peter I of Brazil is declared the constitutional emperor of Brazil.
OctoberampampndashDecember ampampndash Congress of Verona: Russia, Austria and Prussia approve French intervention in Spain.
Greek War of Independence: Nafplion falls to the Greek rebels.
Congregation of St. Basil founded in France.
Peter I is crowned as Emperor of Brazil (''see'' The reign of Pedro I, 1822–31).
Gioachino Rossini's ''Semiramide'' is first performed.

Explorer James Weddell's expedition to Antarctica reaches latitude 74°15'ampnbspS and longitude 34°16'45quotampnbspW: the southernmost position any ship had reached before, a record that will hold for more than 80 years.
Agustin de Iturbide, Emperor of Mexico, abdicates thus ending the short-lived First Mexican Empire.
Eleven-year-old Franz Liszt gives a concert after which he is personally congratulated by Ludwig van Beethoven.
Raffles Institution established as the Singapore Institution by the founder of Singapore, Sir Stamford Raffles.
The congress of Central America declares absolute independence from Spain, Mexico, and any other foreign nation, including North America, and a Republican system of government is established.
The Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls in Rome is almost completely destroyed by fire.
Simón Bolívar is named President of Peru.
Joseph Smith, Jr. clamied in 1838 that on this day he had first come to the place where the Golden plates were stored, having been directed there by God through an angel.
First Burmese War: Burmese attack the British on Shapura, an island close to Chittagong.
Medical journal ''The Lancet'' is founded by Thomas Wakley in London.

James Monroe first introduces the Monroe Doctrine in the State of the Union Address, declaring that any European attempts to recolonize the Americas would be considered a hostile act towards the United States.
After much controversy, Michael Faraday is finally elected as a member of the Royal Society with only one vote against him.
The Ashanti crush British forces in the Gold Coast, killing the British governor Sir Charles MacCarthy (see also Wars between Britain and Ashanti in Ghana and Ashanti Confederacy).
The Westminster Review, No1. is published.
Simón Bolívar is proclaimed dictator of Peru.
Chumash Revolt of 1824 begins against the Spanish presence in The Californias.
Florida State Capitol moves from St. Augustine, Florida to Tallahassee, Florida
The United States War Department creates the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
The Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1824 is signed.
MayampampndashJuly ampampndash King Kamehameha II of Hawaii and his Queen Consort Kamāmalu make a state visit to London, where they both die of smallpox.
Beethoven's ''Symphony No. 9'', premieres in Vienna.
The British take Rangoon, Burma in the First Anglo-Burmese War.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is established in Great Britain.
Lafayette visits the United States, departing in September 7, 1825
With his crew and 29 convicts aboard the ''Amity'', John Oxley arrives at and founds the Moreton Bay Penal Settlement at what is now Redcliffe in Queensland, Australia, after leaving Sydney.
Charles X succeeds his brother Louis XVIII as King of France.
The Edinburgh Town Council founds the Edinburgh Municipal Fire Brigade, the first fire brigade in Britain, under the leadership of  James Braidwood.
Joseph Aspdin patents Portland Cement.
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (the first technological university in the English-speaking world) is founded in Troy, New York.
In the worst flood to date in Saint Petersburg, water rises 421ampnbspcm above normal and 200 lose their lives.
The first sod is turned in Ontario, for the first of four Welland Canals (the canal opens for a trial run exactly 5 years later to the day).
U.S. presidential election, 1824: None of the four candidates for U.S. President gain a majority of the electoral votes, so the election is thrown into the U.S. House of Representatives.
Battle of Ayacucho: Peruvian forces defeat the Spanish.
Chief Pushmataha of the Choctaw Nation dies in Washington.
The First American Fraternity, Chi Phi (ΧΦ), is founded at Princeton University.
King Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies is succeeded by his son Francis I of the Two Sicilies.
Vendsyssel-Thy, once part of the Jutland peninsula that formed westernmost Denmark, becomes an island after a flood drowns its 1ampnbspkm wide isthmus.
After no presidential candidate receives a majority of electoral votes, the United States House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams President of the United States.
Simón Bolívar gives up his title of dictator of Peru and takes the alternative title of ''El Libertador''.
The Creek cede the last of their lands in Georgia to the United States government, and migrate west.
John Quincy Adams succeeds James Monroe as President of the United States.

Charles X of France recognizes Haiti, 21 years after it expelled the French following the successful Haitian Revolution, and demands the payment of 150 million gold francs, 30 million of which Haiti must finance through France itself, as down payment.

The Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Beck gains possession of Glücksburg and changes his title to Friedrich Wilhelm, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg. The line of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg later becomes the Royal House of Greece, Denmark and Norway.
Uruguay secedes from Brazil (see Uruguay's independence).

Malden Island (an uninhabited island in the central Pacific Ocean) is discovered. !-- this is really not noteworthy, but i can't think of a better place to put it for now. Can't find a quottimeline of discoveriesquot or such --
Bolivia gains its independence from Spain as a republic with the instigation of Simón Bolívar.

Gregor MacGregor issues a £300,000 loan with 2.5% interest through the London bank of Thomas Jenkins amp Company.  His actions lead to the Panic of 1825, the first modern stock market crash in London.
September ampampndash The Lady Margaret Boat Club is founded by 12 members of St John's College, Cambridge.
General Hendrik Merkus de Kock lifts the siege of Jogjakarta, the first major action of the Java War.
The world's first modern railway, the Stockton and Darlington Railway, opens in England.
The Miramichi Fire breaks out in New Brunswick.
The PS Comet II sinks off Gourock with the loss of 62 lives.
The Erie Canal opens, providing passage from Albany, New York to Buffalo and Lake Erie.
December ampampndash The Decembrist Revolt breaks out in Russia, but is thoroughly suppressed.
Nicholas I of Russia succeeds his older brother Alexander I.
The Menai Suspension Bridge, built by engineer Thomas Telford, is opened between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales.
Unitarian Bernardino Rivadavia becomes the first President of Argentina.
University College London is founded, under the name ''University of London''.
Swaminarayan wrote the Shikshapatri, an important test within the Swaminarayan faith.
The American Temperance Society is founded.
Samuel Morey patents the internal combustion engine.
Pedro I of Brazil abdicates as King of Portugal.
June ampampndash Photography: Nicéphore Niépce makes a true photograph.
June 15 ampndash The Auspicious Incident: Mahmud II, sultan of Ottoman Empire, crushes the last mutiny of janissaries in Istanbul.
The Pan-American Congress of Panama tries (unsuccessfully) to unify the American republics.
Early July ampampndash Ludwig van Beethoven puts the finishing touches on the ''String Quartet in C sharp Minor, Opus 131'', the jewel in the crown of his late string quartets.
Former US Presidents Thomas Jefferson and John Adams both die on the 50th Anniversary of the signing of the United States Declaration of Independence.
The last ''auto-da-fé'' is held in Valencia.
August ampampndash The town of Crawford Notch suffers a landslide.  Those killed include the Willey family, after whom Mount Willey is named.
The first Cowes Regatta is held on the Isle of Wight in the UK.
Construction of the Rideau Canal begins in Canada.
Opening of the Monkland and Kirkintilloch Railway in Scotland.
The Eggnog Riot breaks out at the United States Military Academy in West Point, New York during the early morning hours, but is squelched by Christmas chapel service.
Major Edmund Lockyer arrives at King George Sound to take possession of the western part of Australia, establishing a settlement near Albany.
Battle of Ituzaingo (Passo do Rosário): A force of the Brazilian Imperial Army meets Argentine–Uruguayan troops in combat.
The Baltimore amp Ohio Railroad is incorporated, becoming the first railroad in America offering commercial transportation of both people and freight.
Brazilian marines sail up the Rio Negro and attack the temporary naval base of Carmen de Patagones, Argentina they are defeated by the local citizens.
Shrigley Abduction: Ellen Turner, a wealthy heiress in Cheshire, England, is abducted by Edward Gibbon Wakefield, the future politician in colonial New Zealand.
''Freedom's Journal'', the first African-American owned and published newspaper in the United States, is founded in New York City by John Russwurm.
April ampampndash Ottoman Algeria: Husain Dei slaps the French consul Decalina on the face, eventually leading to war and French rule in Algeria.
April 8 ampndash Battle of Monte Santiago: A squadron of the Brazilian Imperial Navy defeats Argentine vessels in a major naval engagement.
UK: George Canning succeeds Lord Liverpool as British Prime Minister.
Greek War of Independence ampndash Battle of Phaleron: Ottoman troops defeats the Greek rebels.
May 24 ampndash The Royal Netherlands Navy's British-built paddle steamer ''Curaçao'' makes the first Transatlantic Crossing by steam, from Hellevoetsluis to Paramaribo.

July 9 ampndash  Zarafa, a giraffe presented by the Ottoman Viceroy of Egypt, Mehmet Ali Pasha, to King Charles X of France, the first to be seen in Europe for over three centuries, walks from  Marseilles to Paris.
The Maryland Democratic Party is founded by supporters of Andrew Jackson in Baltimore and hosts its first meeting at the Baltimore Atheneum.
Romanian inventor Petrache Poenaru receives a French patent for the invention of the first fountain pen with a replaceable ink cartridge.
Greek War of Independence: The Treaty of London between France, Britain, and Russia, demands that the Turks agree to an armistice in Greece.
Kingdom of Hawaii: The Diocese of Honolulu is founded.
UK: Frederick John Robinson, 1st Viscount Goderich, becomes Prime Minister of the UK, following the death of George Canning.
Finland: The Great Fire of Turku destroys 3/4 of the city, with many human casualties.

Joseph Smith, Jr. clamied in 1838 that on this day he had taken the Golden plates from the place where they were stored, and that he began writing down the Book of Mormon from them the following December.
Russo-Persian War, 1826-1828: The Russians under Ivan Paskevich storm Yerevan, ending a millennium of Muslim domination in Eastern Armenia.

Greek War of Independence ampndash Battle of Navarino: British, French, and Russian naval forces destroy the Turko-Egyptian fleet in Greece. This is the last naval action to be fought under sail alone.
France: The Vicomte de Martignac succeeds the Comte de Villèle as Prime Minister of France.
UK: The Duke of Wellington succeeds Lord Goderich as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Treaty of Turkmenchay: Russian-Persian peace treaty: Russia captures Eastern Armenia from Persia.
Bahía Blanca is founded.
Feral child: Kaspar Hauser is discovered in Nuremberg, Germany.
Gran Colombia – Peru War: President Simón Bolívar declares war on Peru.
Portugal: King Miguel I overthrows his niece Queen Maria II, beginning the Liberal Wars.
William Corder is hanged at Bury St. Edmunds, England, for the murder of Maria Marten at the Red Barn a year ago.
South America: Brazil and Argentina recognize the independence of Uruguay.  Simón Bolívar declares himself dictator of Gran Colombia.
Russo-Turkish War, 1828-1829: Varna is taken by the Russian army.
Anouvong, ruler of the Kingdom of Vientiane, is deposed and the kingdom is annexed by Siam.  During the war, the city of Vientiane is obliterated by Siamese forces.
U.S. presidential election: Andrew Jackson is elected President of the United States.
Andrew Jackson succeeds John Quincy Adams as the  seventh President of the United States of America.
Felix Mendelssohn performs St Matthew Passion. The success of this performance sparks a revival of interest in the music of Johann Sebastian Bach.

Greece receives autonomy from the Ottoman Empire. This effectively ends the Greek War of Independence. Greece continues to seek full independence through diplomatic negotiations with the Empire as well as with Russia, France and Britain.
Pope Pius VIII succeeds Pope Leo XII as the 253rd pope.

AprilampampndashSeptember ampampndash Felix Mendelssohn pays his first visit to Britain. This includes the first London performance of his concert overture to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and his trip to Fingal's Cave.ampamp{{cite journal|first=George|last=Grove|authorlink=George Grove|title=Mendelssohn's Scotch Symphony|jstor=904111|journal=The Musical Times|volume=45|issue=740|date=1 October 1904|page=644}}ampamp
Vicente Guerrero becomes the president of Mexico.
The Mexican city of Cuautla, Morelos, is founded.
Joseph Smith claims to receive the Aaronic Priesthood from John the Baptist.
''The Philadelphia Inquirer'' is founded as ''The Pennsylvania Inquirer''.
The Swan River Colony (later to become the cities of Perth and Fremantle) is founded in Western Australia. This secures the western 'third' of the Australian landmass for the British.
Slave trade: {{HMS|Pickle}} captures the armed slave ship ''Voladora'' off the coast of Cuba.
Russo-Turkish War, 1828-1829: Russian Field-Marshal Hans Karl von Diebitsch launches the Transbalkan offensive, which brings the Russian army within 68ampnbspkm of Istanbul.
In the United States, William Burt obtains the first patent for a form of typewriter.
France: The Prince de Polignac succeeds the Vicomte de Martignac as Prime Minister of France.
First ascent of Finsteraarhorn, the highest summit of the Bernese Alps.
Mrs. Helen Dance, wife of the captain of the ship ''Sulphur'', cuts down a tree to mark the day of the founding of the town of Perth, Western Australia.
Russo-Turkish War, 1828-1829: The Treaty of Adrianople gains for Russia some territory at the mouth of the Danube and along the eastern coast of the Black Sea.
South African College inaugurated in Cape Town.
Rail transport: Stephenson's ''Rocket'' wins the Rainhill Trials.
The original Welland Canal opens for a trial run with a ceremony at Port Dalhousie.
India: In the face of fierce opposition, British Lord William Bentinck carries a regulation declaring that all who abet suttee in India are guilty of culpable homicide.
LaGrange College (now the University of North Alabama) opens its doors, becoming the first publicly chartered college in Alabama.
January 27 ampndash Robert Y. Hayne of South Carolina debates the question of states' rights vs. federal authority with Daniel Webster of Massachusetts in the United States Congress.
Greece is liberated from the Ottoman forces as the final result of the Greek War of Independence.

''Craig vs. Missouri'': The United States Supreme Court rules that state loan certificates are unconstitutional because they were bills of credit emitted by a state in violation of Article I, Section 10 of the Constitution.
The Book of Mormon is published in Palmyra, New York.

Joseph Smith and 5 others organize the Church of Christ (later renamed the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints), the first formally organized church of the Latter Day Saint movement, in northwestern New York.
Ecuador separates from Gran Colombia.
The United States Congress passes the Indian Removal Act.
William IV succeeds his brother George IV as King of the United Kingdom.
France invades Algeria (see French period in Algeria).

The General Assembly's Institution, now the Scottish Church College, one of the pioneering institutions that ushered the Bengal Renaissance, is founded by Alexander Duff and Raja Ram Mohan Roy, in Calcutta, India.
Barthélemy Thimonnier is granted a patent (#7454) for a sewing machine in France it chains stitches at 200/minute.
Uruguay adopts its first constitution.
Greece grants citizenship to Jews.
France: The July Revolution begins (see also 1830 in France).
France: Louis Philippe becomes King of the French.
France: Duc de Broglie becomes Prime Minister.
The Belgian Revolution begins.
Edwin Beard Budding is granted a patent for the invention of the lawnmower.
The Liverpool and Manchester Railway opens, the world's first intercity passenger railway operated solely by steam locomotives.
The Belgian Revolution ends by liberating Brussels from the United Kingdom of the Netherlands.
The Provisional Government in Brussels declares the creation of the independent state of Belgium, in revolt against the United Kingdom of the Netherlands.
October ampampndash Start of the Regeneration in Switzerland: more liberal constitutions adopted in most cantons.
France: Jacques Laffitte succeeds the Duc de Broglie as Prime Minister.
Ferdinand II becomes King of the Two Sicilies.
The Whig Charles Grey, 2nd Earl Grey succeeds Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The Polish insurrection begins in Warsaw against Russian rule.
Hector Berlioz's most famous work, ''Symphonie Fantastique'', has its world premiere in Paris.
The independence of Belgium is recognized by the Great Powers.
